file_metadata.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2
file_metadata.title: Dynamic Structure Discovery and Repair for 3D Cell Assemblages

chunks.text: Many organisms can regenerate their bodies, but the mechanisms underlying this ability remain unclear. This paper introduces a cell-to-cell communication model that enables 3D cell arrangements to discover and maintain their structure in the face of random cell death. Simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach for Planarian worm-like shapes, but the model is generalizable to any shape.
chunks.chunk_summary: A novel cell-to-cell communication model allows 3D cell structures to discover and maintain their morphology despite cell death.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: Biological organisms exhibit regenerative capabilities, raising questions about how morphological information is encoded and stored. While genetic encoding is traditionally considered the primary mechanism, evidence suggests alternative mechanisms may be involved, particularly in cases where morphological changes are regenerated after lesions, without genetic encoding opportunities.
chunks.chunk_summary: Evidence challenges the traditional view of genetic encoding as the sole mechanism for storing morphological information, suggesting alternative mechanisms are at play.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: This paper proposes a dynamic, distributed messaging mechanism for representing and maintaining morphological structure. This mechanism, unlike static genetic encoding, integrates information across cells, enabling detection of missing cells and triggering regrowth of damaged parts. An agent-based model demonstrates the mechanism's effectiveness in maintaining a 3D flatworm structure despite random cell destruction.
chunks.chunk_summary: A dynamic messaging mechanism, unlike genetic encoding, allows for distributed representation and maintenance of morphological structure, enabling regeneration.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: A key challenge in biology and biomedicine is understanding how cells cooperate to build and maintain complex anatomical structures over time, counteracting aging, cancer, and tissue damage.  Planarian flatworms, with their remarkable regenerative abilities, serve as a model species. While gene regulation models are advancing, testable models of cellular communication explaining pattern memory are still needed.  Developing such models is crucial for translating molecular-genetic insights into practical strategies for regenerative medicine, birth defects, cancer, and bioengineering.
chunks.chunk_summary: Understanding cellular communication and pattern memory in regeneration is crucial for developing practical applications in regenerative medicine and related fields.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: Previous approaches to structural maintenance in artificial life have used genetic algorithms, agent-based models, and cellular automata. These models often evolve gene regulatory networks or cellular automata rules to generate and maintain specific shapes, sometimes demonstrating emergent wound healing capabilities. However, these models typically rely on genetic encoding to define cell behavior, whereas the proposed model uses a dynamic messaging mechanism that does not depend on local genetic information.
chunks.chunk_summary: Past models of structural maintenance often rely on genetic encoding, while the proposed model utilizes a dynamic messaging mechanism independent of local genetic information.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: The proposed cell-to-cell communication mechanism allows cells to send and forward messages containing path information. This information is used to detect missing cells along a path, triggering regeneration. A 2D example illustrates how a packet containing path segments can detect and repair missing cells along its route.  Regeneration occurs only along the specific path of the packet, requiring multiple packets to cover all damaged areas.
chunks.chunk_summary: Cells send messages with path information to detect and regenerate missing cells along the message path.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: The agent-based model (ABM) simulates cells as agents with unique IDs and 3D locations within a rhombic dodecahedral honeycomb structure, resembling a Planarian worm. Each cell has up to 12 neighbors and can hold and send packets. Packets contain vectors describing their path, with newer vectors at the top of the list. Cells generate packets, send them to neighbors, and can hold packets based on specific criteria. Packets can change direction or backtrack, regenerating dead cells during backtracking.
chunks.chunk_summary: The ABM simulates cells as agents within a 3D structure, exchanging packets containing path information for structure maintenance and regeneration.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: The model runs in discrete-time cycles, with cells performing sensing (receiving and processing packets, regenerating dead neighbors) and acting (sending packets). Local interactions between cells through packet exchange lead to emergent structure maintenance. Stochasticity is involved in determining packet direction and cell death.  The model aims to investigate structure monitoring and regeneration in 3D cell structures, particularly in response to random damage.
chunks.chunk_summary: The model simulates cell communication and regeneration through discrete-time cycles, with stochastic processes influencing packet direction and cell death.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: Simulation experiments evaluated the model's ability to maintain a 3D Planarian-like structure (2712 cells) with a 90% alive cell threshold. Cell death was simulated at various probabilities (_DeathProb_) starting at cycle 80.  The number of packets generated per cycle (_PacketFreq_), minimum bends before backtracking (_MinBends_), minimum top vector length for bending (_MinTopLen_), and bending probability (_BendProb_) were varied. 50,688 simulations were run with different parameter combinations and random seeds to explore the parameter space and assess the model's robustness.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulations tested the model's ability to maintain a 3D structure under varying cell death rates and communication parameters.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: Out of 50,688 simulations, 28,961 with _DeathProb_ > 0 maintained 90% alive cells for the entire 500 cycles. The number of successful simulations decreased with increasing _DeathProb_. ANOVA revealed significant main effects for all independent variables except _BendProb_, indicating its lack of relevance for structure maintenance.  A negative correlation was found between _DeathProb_ and cycles above threshold, while a positive correlation existed between _PacketFreq_ and cycles above threshold, reaching an asymptote due to redundancy.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulations showed successful structure maintenance under various death rates, with _PacketFreq_ positively impacting survival and _BendProb_ showing no significant effect.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: A moderate _MinBends_ value (3) performed best, balancing coverage and risk of packet loss. Increasing _MinTopLen_ increased packet length and risk of loss, making lower values preferable at higher _DeathProb_. The interaction between _MinTopLen_ and _MinBends_ showed an optimal combination of _MinTopLen_ = 1 and _MinBends_ = 3, highlighting the importance of bend number for coverage.
chunks.chunk_summary: Optimal parameter combinations for structure maintenance were identified, highlighting the trade-off between packet coverage and risk of loss due to cell death.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed cell-to-cell communication mechanism for structure maintenance under random cell death. The model is hypothesized to be capable of regenerating from more systematic cuts or lesions, provided packets can cover the excised cells. The mechanism is generalizable to various structures, with maintainability depending on cell death patterns and packet complexity.
chunks.chunk_summary: The model's success in random cell death scenarios suggests potential for regenerating from more complex damage, with generalizability to various structures.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: Bi-directional cell communication _in vivo_ occurs through various media, including chemical signals, physical forces, and bioelectric signaling. Bioelectric signaling, particularly developmental bioelectricity, is of special interest due to its role in cell communication, memory, and decision-making during development and regeneration.  Cells regulate bioelectric dynamics using ion channels and pumps, and communicate via gap junctions, which influence growth and form during regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signaling, particularly through gap junctions, plays a crucial role in cell communication and regeneration.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2

chunks.text: This paper introduces the first agent-based model for 3D cell structure discovery and repair, demonstrating its efficacy in maintaining a Planarian-like shape under random cell death. Future work will investigate the model's behavior with non-uniform cell death (e.g., clustered death) and regeneration from cuts, as observed in Planaria. The hypothesis is that the model can regenerate from various types of damage with appropriate communication parameters.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future research will explore the model's ability to handle non-uniform cell death and regeneration from cuts, further validating its potential for understanding and manipulating biological regeneration.
chunks.authors: Giordano B. S. Ferreira1, Max Smiley1, Matthias Scheutz1, Mike Levin2
